questions.text: Which of the following arteries is being palpated in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
The posterior tibial artery is palpated between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal tendon, as shown in the image.

The posterior tibial artery can be felt by keeping the foot relaxed between plantar and dorsiflexion and palpating against the distal tibia behind and below the medial malleolus,approximately one-third of a line connecting the posterior border of the medial malleolus to the calcaneal tendon(Achilles tendon)

Other options:

Dorsalis pedis artery: 

  • palpated against the underlying tarsals
  • lateral to the tendon of extensor hallucis longus from the midpoint between the malleoli to the proximal end of the first intermetatarsal space. 

Popliteal artery: 

  • most difficult of the peripheral pulses to feel because the artery lies deep in the popliteal fossa.
  • examined with the subject lying supine or prone, with the knee flexed in order to relax the tense popliteal fascia that roofs the popliteal fossa.
  • felt over the midline of the fossa by deep pressure against the popliteal surface of the femur. 

Arteries of the lower limb are:

questions.text: An oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve of a 30-year-old athlete was recorded. If curve 3 represents the dissociation curve during rest, how would the graph shift if he was exercising?
questions.solution:
From the given scenario, during exercise, the oxygen hemoglobin curve shifts considerably towards the right and is denoted by the curve 4.

Curve 3 represents the normal oxygen hemoglobin curve during rest. 

Conditions that cause a right shift (curve 3 to curve 4) in the oxygen hemoglobin curve are: (Conditions with the increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilize O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature, heat
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis

Conditions that cause a left shift (curve 3 to curve 2)  in the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve are:

  • Decreased carbon dioxide
  • ↑ pH of the blood
  • ↓ in the temperature of the body

Curve 1 represents the Myoglobin-O2 binding curve. It is a rectangular hyperbola (unlike a sigmoid curve of the oxygen-hemoglobin curve). This is because it only has a single oxygen binding site. It is present in muscles in large amounts and can provide oxygen to muscles even at low blood oxygen levels.

questions.text: The following image shows the normal electrophoresis of serum proteins. Which of the following bands is much prominent in nephrotic syndrome ?
questions.solution:
The band that is marked as C in the given image corresponds to α2 globulin. This band becomes much prominent in nephrotic syndrome.

α2  macroglobulin, being a relatively bigger protein compared to others is not lost through urine in nephrotic syndrome. Hence the α2 band which includes α2 macroglobulin is very prominent in serum protein electrophoresis of a nephrotic syndrome patient.

The following image shows the bands with their corresponding proteins in normal serum electrophoresis.

Certain common diseases and their electrophoretic pattern:

Condition  Electrophoretic pattern
Chronic infections Smooth increase in gamma globulins
Multiple myeloma Gamma globulin part is increased (M BAND)
Liver cirrhosis Reduced albumin and compensatory increase in globulin
Primary immune deficiency Gamma globulin reduced
α1 antitrypsin deficiency α1 band is thin and even lost sometimes

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythromytosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A patient with a history of peptic ulcer underwent upper GI endoscopic biopsy of the stomach. The biopsy is stained with a special stain and shown in the image. What is the special stain used?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the bacilli (Helicobacter pylori).

On antral biopsy, H. pylori organisms are seen abundantly within the surface mucus layer, but they are difficult to visualize with routine hematoxylin (H&E) stains. Organisms are most easily demonstrated with special stains like Warthin starry silver stain or Giemsa stain.

Image: Warthin-Starry silver stain showing Helicobacter pylori colonized on the surface of the regenerative epithelium.

Image: Giemsa stain showing Helicobacter pylori in a case of chronic gastritis.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

Staining technique Cells/inclusions stained Disorders
H&E Most common stain used in routine histopathology Commonly used for all slides
Papanicolaou stain Universal stain for cytological preparations Cytological studies
PAS Demonstrate glycogen, mucin, fungi, macrophages  Whipple's disease, adenocarcinomas, and glycogen-positive tumors (Ewings sarcoma, renal cell carcinoma)
PTAH (Phosphotungstic acid hematoxylin) Fibrin Gliosis, Ependymomas, Tumours of skeletal muscles, Fibrin deposits
Alcian blue For acid mucins: Positive stain for mucins of the intestinal mucosa and negative stain for mucins of gastric mucosa and Brunner's gland Barrett's esophagus, Gastric disorders
Perl's Prussian blue Demonstrate hemosiderin and iron Hemochromatosis 
Masson–Fontana stain Demonstrate melanin Nevus and malignant melanoma
von Kossa method Demonstrate calcium Calcification of tissues
Van Gieson stain

Demonstrate collagen in; Differentiate amyloid from collagen

 Spindle-cell neoplasm; Delineate extent of fibrosis 
Masson trichrome stain Demonstrate collagen and muscle Connective tissue disorders, muscle and fibroblast tumors, liver cirrhosis, neuromuscular diseases 
Reticulin stain Demonstrate reticulin fibers Distinguish epithelial from non-epithelial neoplasm, Hodgkin's lymphoma, early cirrhosis of the liver, myelofibrosis
Verhoeff's method Demonstrate elastic fibers Malignant hypertension, arteriovenous malformation aneurysms, Marfan's syndrome, emphysema lung
Oil red O Sudan Black Sudan III/IV Demonstrate fat/lipids Fatty liver-fat embolism-fibroma vs. thecoma of the ovary-liposarcoma 

Microbiology stains:

Stain  Uses
Ziehl–Neelsen Stain Mycobacteria (all species, including Mycobacterium leprae), Nocardia spp. Cyst of Cryptosporidium parvum, Isospora spp., and Cyclospora spp., Head of sperms
Masson’s Fontana Melanin and argentaffin Cells
Gomori Methenamine Silver Fungi
Luxol Fast Blue (LFB) Myelin
Phosphotungstic Acid-hematoxylin Cross striations of skeletal muscle, fibrin
Toluidine blue Mast cells
Warthin–Starry Helicobacter pylori, spirochetes
Van Gieson Collagen fibres
Mucicarmine Mucin, Cryptococcus capsule

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, soar throat, and dyspnea. The examination finding of the oral cavity is shown below. What will be the media used to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with pseudomembrane over tonsil is suggestive of diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheria. Loeffler's serum slope is the medium for diagnosis of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. 

Loeffler's serum slope (shown in the image below) is an enriched medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. It is not a selective medium as other organisms can also grow on this medium. Rapid growth occurs within 6-8 hours. Colonies appear at first as small, opaque discs. They increase in size on continued incubation and may acquire a yellow tint.

Corynebacterium diphtheria (also called Klebs-Loeffler bacillus) is a gram-positive bacillus with clubbing at both ends. They possess characteristic polymetaphosphate granules also called metachromatic granules.

Diphtheria is characterized by mild fever, sore throat, difficulty swallowing, malaise, loss of appetite, and hoarseness (if the larynx is involved). The hallmark is a grey-white pseudomembrane over the mucous lining of the tonsils (most commonly), pharynx, larynx, or nares. It is tightly adherent to the underlying tissue, and any attempt to dislodge the membrane may cause bleeding. 

A few patients develop massive swelling of the tonsils and present with bull-neck diphtheria, due to edema of the submandibular and paratracheal region.

Other options:

Lowenstein-Jenson medium is shown in the given image. It is a selective medium used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis culture. Malachite green imparts a green colour and makes Lowenstein Jenson medium a selective media by inhibiting other bacteria. 

Middlebrook’s media is a liquid culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is shown in the image below.

Thayer-Martin medium is shown in the image below. It is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The antimicrobials present in it, suppress the growth of other commensal organisms which may inhibit the growth of N.gonorrhoeae. It contains antimicrobials like vancomycin, colistin, and nystatin in chocolate agar.

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media

Appropriate culture media for various bacteria:

Organism Medium for culture
Staph aureus Mannitol salt agar
ludlam’s medium
salt milk agar
Strep. Pyogenes Crystal violet blood agar
Neisseria meningitidis Thayer martin medium
Corynebacterium Potassium tellurite agar
Tinsdale medium
Mcleod medium
B.anthrax PLET medium
B.cereus MYPA (Mannitol egg yolk phenol red polymyxin agar)
PEMBA(polymyxin in egg yolk mannitol bromothymol blue agar
Clostridium  CCFA ( cefoxitin cycloserine fructose agar)
Shigella DCA, XLD, SSA
Salmonella Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium
Vibrio TCBS
Monsur GTTA
Pseudomonas Cetrimide agar
B.pseudomallei Ashdown medium
H. influenza Fildes agar
Levinthal medium
Bordetella Bordet-Gengou glycerine potato blood agar
Brucella Casteneda medium
B.burgdorferi BSK medium
Campylobacter

Skirrow's, Butzler's and Campy BAP media
Legionella pneumophilia

BCYE medium
Leptospira EMJH medium

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the Dose response curve shown in the image below:

choices.text: Drug A is more potent than Drug B
Drug C is more potent than Drug A

questions.solution:
In the above image, Drug A is the most potent drug

Potency

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response.
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • The more the curve is on the left in a dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency.
  • Thus, in the above image, the potency is Drug A > Drug C > Drug B.

Drug B is a competitive antagonist (Option D)

In competitive antagonism, the DRC is shifted to the right whereas in non-competitive antagonism the DRC is flattened.

Thus in the above image Drug B is the Competitive antagonist while Drug C is the non-competitive antagonist.

Efficacy

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug.
  • It expresses the effect produced by the receptors when bound by a certain drug.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.
  • Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is Drug A = Drug B > Drug C.

questions.text: What is the correct statement regarding the wound indicated by the red arrow in the given image of the skull?

choices.text: It is an Exit wound because the outer table appears bevelled
It is an entry wound because the outer table appears bevelled
It is an Exit wound because the inner table appears bevelled
It is an entry wound because the inner table appears bevelled

questions.solution:
In the given image, bevelling is seen on the outer table and a punched out hole is seen on the inner table. So, it is an exit wound.

Entry wound: The initial contact of the missile punches a clean hole through the outer table of the skull. Where the bullet emerges internally, the inner table is then unsupported and a cone-shaped plug is detached, forming a crater that is appreciably larger than the external hole.

  • Bevelling: inner table
  • Punched out hole: outer table

Exit wound: If the bullet traverses the cranium and penetrates the opposite side, the same pattern occurs, this time with the small hole on the inner table and the crater on the outside.

  • Bevelling: outer table
  • Punched out hole: inner table

A 'rat-hole' appearance of the entry wound of a shotgun can be seen from 30 cm to 5 meters of range:

  • Circular rat-hole wound without peripheral satellite pellet holes is seen in 30cm-1m range.
  • Central rat-hole wound with peripheral satellite pellet holes is seen in 1m-5m range.

Ricochet: This is when the bullet hits an intervening object before hitting the desired target. Due to this, it tumbles towards the target and enters it obliquely, rather than head-on.

Related Pearl: Difference between Wound of Entry and Exit

Characteristics

Wound of entry

Wound of exit

Size

Smaller than the diameter of the bullet.

In close discharge, skin is torn, hence size is increased.

Bigger than the diameter of the bullet.

Margin

Inverted

Everted

Soiling of wound

+ve

-ve

Abrasion collar

+ve

-ve

Contusion collar

+ve

-ve

Grease collar

+ve

-ve

Bleeding

Less

More

Foreign bodies

+ve

-ve

Dispersion of pallets (shotgun)

+ve

-ve

Protrusion of fat

-ve

+ve

Bright red (Carboxy Hb)

+ve (Near shot)

-ve

X-ray Metallic Ring

+ve

-ve

Muzzle impression

+ve (contact shot)

-ve

Blast effect

+ve (contact shot)

-ve

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of right ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely?
questions.solution:
The image shows quinsy also known as a peritonsillar abscess.

Peritonsillar abscess or quinsy is a collection of pus in the peritonsillar space which lies between the capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscle. It usually follows an episode of acute tonsillitis when the crypta magna gets infected and gets sealed off. An intratonsillar abscess then forms which then bursts through the capsule to reach the peritonsillar space.

Usually, it is unilateral though occasionally bilateral abscesses are recorded.

It presents with marked odynophagia such that the patient cannot even swallow his saliva which dribbles from the angle of his mouth. The patient is usually dehydrated. Other features include a muffled and thick speech, often called a hot potato voice, sore throat, ipsilateral otalgia, torticollis, and fever.

On examination, the tonsil, pillars, and soft palate are congested and enlarged. The uvula is congested and oedematous and pushed to the opposite side. Mucopus covering the tonsil is seen. Jugulodigastric lymph nodes are enlarged and tender.

CECT, submandibular ultrasonography, and MRI are better suited for visualizing the abscess and its extent. Submandibular ultrasonography is also helpful for incision and drainage.

 Management of peritonsillar abscess:

  • Hospitalization
  • Intravenous fluids to address dehydration
  • High-dose intravenous antibiotics to cover aerobes and anaerobes
  • Analgesics for pain relief
  • Drainage by needle aspiration or incision and drainage
  • Tonsillectomy when there is airway obstruction or recurrence.

Incision and drainage of the abscess at the point of the maximum bulge above the upper pole of the tonsil or just lateral to the point of junction of the anterior pillar with a line drawn through the base of the uvula.

 Complications of peritonsillar abscess are:

  • Retropharyngeal abscess
  • Laryngeal edema
  • Parapharyngeal abscess
  • Septicemia
  • Pneumonitis/ lung abscess
  • Jugular vein thrombosis
  • Spontaneous hemorrhage from carotid artery/ jugular vein.

questions.text: A tumor in the anterior pituitary pressing on the optic chiasma will present as a case of ____.
questions.solution:
A lesion in the optic chiasma will present as bitemporal hemianopia, due to the decussation of nasal fibres which are affected.

Other notable defects:

  • Pie in the sky defects
    • Superior quadrantic hemianopia
    • Involvement of Meyer’s loop - inferior fibers of optic radiations
    • Contralateral temporal lobe
  • Pie in the floor defects
    • Inferior quadrantic hemianopia
    • Involvement of Baum’s loop - superior fibers of optic radiations
    • Contralateral parietal lobe
  • Homonymous hemianopia
    • Involvement of retrochiasmal regions such as optic tract, geniculate body, optic radiations.
    • Sparing of the macula and more congruous field defect (both sides have the same extent of field loss) when the occipital cortex is involved.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A newly pregnant woman from a rural area registered in the scheme shown below. Which of the following benefits would she receive under this scheme?

choices.text: At least 4 antenatal checkups and 6 homebased newborn care visits
Free checkup on 9th of every month

questions.solution:
The above image shows the logo of Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA). Under this scheme, all pregnant women will receive a free checkup on the 9th of every month.

Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA):

Benefit: Free checkup on the 9th of every month.

Objective: Improve the quality and coverage of antenatal care, diagnostics, and counseling services.

Implementation: Pregnant women receive at least one check-up in their second or third trimester by a doctor in the PMSMA clinic, specifically on the 9th of every month.

After routine examination, pregnant women are categorized according to the risk factors, and different coloured stickers are pasted on mother and child protection cards.

  • Green sticker: For women with no detected risk factor
  • Red sticker: For women with detected risk factor

Other options:

Option A: Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana (PMMVY):

  • Benefit: Cash incentive of 5000 rupees.
  • Eligibility: Provided to all pregnant women and lactating mothers for the first living child of the
  • family, subject to specific conditions.

Option B: Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN):

  • Benefit: At least 4 antenatal checkups and 6 home-based newborn care visits.
  • Objective: Assured, dignified, and respectful delivery of quality healthcare services at no cost, aiming to end all preventable maternal and newborn deaths.
  • Implementation: Ensures zero tolerance for denial of services to any woman and newborn, providing antenatal checkups and home-based newborn care visits.

Option D: Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY):

  • Benefit: Cash incentive of 1400 rupees.
  • Eligibility: Provided to all pregnant women who undergo institutional delivery in low-performing states.
  • Objective: Promote institutional delivery to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases are included in the scheme, which has the logo as given below?
questions.solution:
The logo shows the NPCDCS scheme that has separate components for cancer and other non-communicable diseases like diabetes, cardiovascular disease and stroke.

The National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke (NPCDCS) has specialized facilities in district hospitals.

It has been implemented in over 100 districts in 21 states.

At the subcentre level under NPCDCS, screening and referral is done.

NOTE: Non-alcoholic fattly liver disease (NAFLD) has been integrated with NPCDCS in 2021.

questions.text: Identify the type of study from the following design.
questions.solution:
The study design given is a prospective cohort study. The study proceeds from cause to effect.

Framingham Heart Study is one of the most famous long-term cardiovascular cohort studies.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause to effect, as exposure has occured but not disease.
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a Cohort Study
    • Types
      • Prospective cohort studies (concurrent cohort studies)
      • Retrospective cohort studies (historical cohort study)
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages and disadvantages

Advantages

Disadvantages

Incidence can be calculated.

Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at same time.

Provides direct estimate of relative risk

Calculation of dose-response ratio

Minimization of certain biases

Cannot be used for uncommon diseases

Uses a large population

Takes a long time to complete

Many common administrative problems

Attrition is high.

Selection of subjects is difficult.

Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate.

Tend to be expensive.

Tends to alter behaviour of subjects: Hawthorne effect.

Ethical problems

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

  • In a case control study, progression is from effect to cause as outcome or disease has already occurred.
  • It is also called retrospective study.
  • Design of Case Control Study

 

    • Steps of Case Control Study
      • Selection of cases and controls
      • Matching
      • Measurement of exposure
      • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
    • Advantages and Disadvantages

Advantages

Disadvantages

Easy to carry out

Rapid and inexpensive

Requires few subjects

Used to investigate rare diseases

No risk to subjects

Different etiological factors can be studied.

Risk factors can be identified.

No attrition problems

Minimal ethical problems

Relies on memory or past records which can give rise to bias

Selection of appropriate control groups may be difficult.

Incidence cannot be measured.

Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors

Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis

Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with the following skin lesions. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing red-purple macules and plaques in an HIV-positive patient is suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma, caused by human herpesvirus 8. It also causes primary effusion lymphoma. 

HHV-8 or Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) is known to cause Kaposi’s sarcoma, especially in immunocompromised persons. Cancer patients receiving chemotherapy, AIDS patients, and organ transplant recipients are all at a high risk of showing signs of infection.

It is one of the currently known human cancer viruses or oncoviruses.

KSHV is a known causative agent of four diseases:

  1. Kaposi's sarcoma
  2. KSHV-associated multicentric Castleman's disease (MCD)
  3. Primary effusion lymphoma

Related Pearl: Oncoviruses and the cancers associated with them

Virus

Genome

Associated cancers 

Hepatitis B

(HBV)

DNA

Hepatocarcinoma

Hepatitis C

(HCV)

RNA

Hepatocarcinoma

Human

T-

lymphotropic

virus (HTLV)

RNA

Adult T-cell leukemia

Human

papilloma

viruses

(HPV)

DNA

Cervical cancer

Oropharyngeal cancer

Anogenital cancer

Kaposi’s

sarcoma-

associated

herpesvirus

(HHV-8)

DNA

Kaposi’s sarcoma, multicentric Castleman's disease

Merkel cell polyomavirus

(MCV)

DNA

Merkel cell carcinoma

Epstein–Barr

virus (EBV)

DNA

Burkitt’s lymphoma, Hodgkin’s lymphoma, Post-transplant lymphoproliferative disease, and Nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

questions.text: A 46-year-old chronic alcoholic male presents to the OPD with fever, headache, shortness of breath, chest pain,  and productive cough for the last two days. On examination, there was bronchial breathing on the right side. A chest x-ray was done. Which is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, history of alcoholism and the CXR findings are highly suggestive of lobar pneumonia caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae. The above chest x-ray shows a bulging fissure sign.

Klebsiella pneumonia is associated mostly with alcoholics and shows upper lobe involvement, cavitation, and pneumatocele (also seen in S.aureus). The patient presents with red currant-jelly sputum.

Bulging fissure sign is classically seen in Klebsiella pneumonia. It represents expansive lobar consolidation causing fissural bulging or displacement by copious amounts of inflammatory exudate within the affected parenchyma. Other diseases that manifest a bulging fissure include any space-occupying process in the lung, such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and tumor.

questions.text: ECG of a patient who was brought to the casualty due to severe chest pain followed by syncope is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given ECG is suggestive of atrial flutter.

The given ECG shows narrow QRS complexes, hence it is supraventricular tachycardia. The RR intervals are regular and the normal P waves are replaced by sawtooth-shaped waves, known as flutter waves.

In atrial flutter, the ventricular rate is determined by the AV conduction ratio. The commonest AV ratio is 2:1. In the above ECG, the rhythm is atrial flutter 4:1 block with an atrial rate of about 270 and a ventricular rate of 68/min.

The image below shows sawtooth shaped waves in atrial flutter.

questions.text: Identify the type of ataxia given below -
questions.solution:
The gait shown in the above video is a cerebellar ataxic gait.

Cerebellar gait ataxia is characterized by a wide base of support, lateral instability of the trunk, and erratic foot placement. There is a loss of balance when attempting to walk on a narrow base. Difficulty maintaining balance when turning is often an early feature. They show considerable variation in their tendency to fall in daily life.

Here, the patient is seen attempting tandem walking and displays improper heel-toe coordination, erratic foot placement, and truncal swaying.

Causes of cerebellar ataxia include stroke, trauma, tumor, hereditary cerebellar degeneration, Wilson's disease, neurodegenerative disorders like multiple-system atrophy (MSA). Alcohol causes both acute and chronic cerebellar ataxia.

Other options:

Option A: Patients with sensory ataxia walk unsteadily with multiple falls, on a narrow base, and tend to look down while walking. They lose balance on walking with their eyes closed or in the dark. Joint sense and vibration sense are diminished. Dorsal column lesions of the spinal cord result in sensory ataxia. 

Option C: Frontal ataxia or shuffling, freezing gait includes a wide base of support, a short stride, shuffling along the floor, and difficulty with starts and turns. Many patients exhibit difficulty with gait initiation which is descriptively characterized as the “slipping clutch” syndrome or gait ignition failure. It is commonly seen in the elderly.

Option D: Spastic gait is characterized by stiffness in the legs, and a tendency to circumduct and scuff the feet. It is associated with an imbalance in muscle tone. Lesions in the corticospinal tract result in spastic gait.

questions.text: A male patient with a history of burns in his left lower limb presented to the OPD with the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's history of burns and the image is suggestive of a Marjolin's ulcer. It is a rare and aggressive form of squamous cell carcinoma that grows from burns, scars, or poorly healing wounds. It presents as an indurated, non-tender ulcer with raised and everted edges with scarring in the surrounding area with marked fibrosis

The ulcer can spread to the lymph nodes when it reaches the normal skin. A wedge biopsy and MRI of the region involved confirm the diagnosis.

Management is by wide excision, for larger ulcers, amputation is done.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic liver disease presents with abdominal distension, jaundice, and pruritis. Ascitic fluid analysis revealed neutrophil count > 650 per cubic mm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario and image of a patient with abdominal distension, jaundice, pruritus, and neutrophil count >650 per mm3, the likely diagnosis is spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.  

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is an acute bacterial infection of the ascitic fluid. It is commonly seen in adults in association with liver cirrhosis. The pathogens involved are Escherichia coli, streptococci, enterococci, and pneumococci. 

In a patient with ascites, SBP presents with fever, and acute abdominal pain. On examination, tachycardia, tachypnea, and signs of peritonitis are seen. Hepatic encephalopathy and gastrointestinal bleeding may also occur. 

Diagnosis is by paracentesis, and an ascitic fluid neutrophil count of >250/mm3 is suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Ascitic fluid culture may reveal pathogenic organisms.

Management is mainly by third-generation cephalosporins such as cefotaxime. Albumin infusion can be given as it decreases the risk of renal failure and improves patient survival. Early diagnosis and treatment improve the prognosis.

Other options:

Option B: Malignant ascites occurs as a complication of intra-abdominal and extra-abdominal malignancies. Patients can present with increasing abdominal girth, generalized abdominal pain, and shortness of breath. Weight loss may be more common. Ascitic fluid analysis reveals a milky or bloody appearance with elevated levels of tumor markers and VEGF (vascular endothelial growth factor). Treatment is by paracentesis and peritoneovenous shunt.

Option C: Ascites is often seen in patients with tubercular peritonitis. Multiple tubercles are seen on the peritoneum. Ascitic fluid analysis reveals a straw-colored fluid with a white blood cell count >500 mm3. Laparoscopy and peritoneal biopsy may be helpful in diagnosis. Management is by supportive and anti-tubercular therapy.  

Option D: Intestinal obstruction can present as pain, abdominal distension, vomiting, and absolute constipation. Abdominal radiographs taken in a supine position are useful in diagnosis. Abdominal radiograph in erect posture shows fluid levels. Management is mainly by insertion of a nasogastric tube, replacement of fluid and electrolytes, and surgery.

questions.text: What is the stage of the breast cancer shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows Peau d'orange appearance of breast which is T4b according to the TNM staging.

Tumour of any size with overlying skin involvement(Peau d'orange appearance) is T4b.

The peau d'orange appearance of the breast occurs due to blockade of sub-dermal lymphatics.The lymphatic blockade gives rise to edema in the breast and tries to swell up. Since the infiltrated skin is tethered to the ligaments of Cooper, the swelling is restricted. The resultant edema deepens the mouth of the sweat glands and hair follicles giving rise to the typical orange peel appearance.

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of carcinoma breast

Tumor (T) Description
Tis Ductal carcinoma in situ / Paget's disease
T1

≤2 cm in greatest dimension

1a >0.1 to 0.5 cm

1b >0.5 to 1 cm

1c >1 to 2 cm
T2 >2 but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension
T3 >5 cm in greatest dimension
T4

Tumor of any size and -

4a – chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)# 

4b – skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peau d’orange, satellite nodules  

4c – 4a + 4b  

4d – inflammatory breast carcinoma(typical skin changes involving >1/3rd of breast)*
Nodes (N) Description
N1 mic Refers to micrometastasis to Lymph node
N1 Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes
N2A Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes
N2B Ipsilateral internal mammary without axillary lymph node involvement
N3A Ipsilateral infraclavicular lymph nodes
N3B Ipsilateral internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes
N3C Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes
Distant metastasis (M) Description
Metastasis absent M0
Metastasis present M1

  

Stages       T , N  M
Stage 0 TisN0 M0
Stage IA T1N0 M0
Stage IB T0,1N1mic M0
Stage IIA T0,1N1 (or) T2N0 M0
Stage IIB T2N1 (or) T3N0 M0
Stage IIIA T0,1,2,3N2 (or) T3N1 M0
Stage IIIB T4 N0,1,2 M0
Stage IIIC

Any T, N3

 M0
Stage IV

Any T, Any N

 M1

#Chest wall includes Serratus anterior, Intercostal muscles, Ribs. Pectoralis muscle is not a part of chest wall.

*Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage IIIB) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud’orange) involving >1/3rd of breast.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered as a benign condition and not included under Tis.

questions.text: You have posted a 43-year-old woman with abnormal uterine bleeding for dilatation and curettage in the minor OT.  Identify the following instrument used in this procedure.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Sim's curette. It is a single-ended uterine curette used for dilatation and curettage.

It is designed to remove tough tissue from the lining of the uterus for biopsy or excision. The curette features a sharp loop tip to aid in the removal of the uterine tissue.

questions.text: A patient with a history of obstructed labor and cesarean section presents with continuous dribbling of urine through vagina on day 7. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of vesicovaginal fistula.

Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is a type of genital fistula, which is an abnormal communication between the genital tract and the urinary tract.

Vesicovaginal fistulae occur mostly due to obstetric injuries such as prolonged labor, and instrumental or manipulative deliveries. Patients present with true incontinence characterized by constant dribbling of urine. The presence of urine in the undergarments is uncomfortable and leads to pruritus and excoriation of the genital area

In obstructed labour, ischemia necrosis occurs as a result of prolonged compression effect on the bladder base between the head and symphysis pubis leading to infection → sloughing → fistula. Thus, it takes around 3–5 days following delivery to produce a fistula.

Clinical assessment by the introduction of a speculum helps to determine the size, number, and location of the fistulae. A methylene blue test helps confirm the diagnosis and determine the type of repair operation.

Small fistulas due to difficult childbirth can heal spontaneously. Most established fistulas need to be repaired vaginally usually after 3 months to allow the inflammation to subside.

The repair operation includes the Latzko procedure. The procedure involves denuding the vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges and approximating the raw surfaces. Another is the Chassar-Moir technique of widely separating the bladder and vagina and suturing them separately in two layers.

Post-operatively, continuous bladder drainage for 14 days along with antibiotics is recommended. Vaginal or speculum examination and intercourse are not advised for 3 months. Avoiding pregnancy for a year is also recommended. A cesarean section is usually done for future pregnancies.

Other options:

Option A: Vesicouterine fistula occurs during cesarean section or uterine rupture or placenta accreta. Patients complain of cyclical hematuria due to the trickling of menstrual blood into the bladder through this anomalous condition. But the urinary continence of the patient remains normal. This is also known as Youssef syndrome. 

Option B: In urethrovaginal fistulae, the patient is continent and dry, but may dribble urine during micturition. This usually follows surgery for a paravaginal cyst or urethral diverticulum, or after a penetrating injury from a fall or criminal abortion. The fistulous opening is visible on speculum examination.

Option C: Ureterovaginal fistulae result from direct injury to the ureter during gynecologic surgery (Eg: Wertheim's procedure for Ca cervix). Urine dribbles from both vagina and urethra post-surgery. The three-swab test will not stain with methylene blue, but with urine.

Related Pearl: Methylene blue - 3 swab test

Procedure:

A catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three (or four) sterile cotton swabs.

50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a catheter.

Results:

  • Upper swabs get wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter: Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Upper swabs get stained - the leak is from the bladder: Vesicovaginal fistula
  • Lower swabs get stained - the leak is from the urethra: Urethrovaginal fistula.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Abdominal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section
Clinical features

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is unable to micturate

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is able to micturate
Methylene blue 3-swab test Middle swab stains with methylene blue   Uppermost swab stains with urine, but not with methylene blue
Intravenous pyelography Normal Hydronephrosis and hydroureter present on the affected side

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the image given below?

choices.text: Skin condition is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexure areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin
Presents only in patients with PCOD
It develops more frequently in obese women with PCOS than in those with PCOS and normal weight

questions.solution:
The condition in the given image is acanthosis nigricans; being a cutaneous marker of insulin resistance, acanthosis nigricans may be found in individuals with or without PCOS.

  • Skin condition is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexure areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.
  • Acanthosis nigricans develops more frequently in obese women with PCOS (50 percent incidence) than in those with PCOS and normal weight (5–10 percent).

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

  • Obesity 
  • Metabolic syndromes (Type 2 diabetes with insulin resistance)
  • Drugs such as Nicotinic acid used to treat hyperlipidemia 
  • Sudden onset of multiple seborrhoeic keratosis 
  • Gastrointestinal malignancies such as adenocarcinoma of the stomach or pancreas

questions.text: With respect to the condition shown below, choose the false statement.

choices.text: Loss of abduction of the arm
Loss of lateral rotation of the arm
Loss of sensation in the lateral 2 fingers
Loss of flexion of the elbow

questions.solution:
The image shows Erb's palsy (waiter's tip deformity) in which there is a loss of sensation over a small area of the lower part of the deltoid.

It is caused by injury to C5, C6 and rarely C7. It is seen most commonly in babies with shoulder dystocia at delivery.

The following are seen in Erb's palsy:

  • Loss of abduction and lateral rotation of the arm
  • Loss of flexion of the elbow
  • Loss of supination of the forearm
  • Loss of biceps, supinator and inverse supinator jerks
  • Loss of sensation over a small area of the lower part of the deltoid

Related Pearl: Erb's and Klumpke's Palsies.

Erb's and Klumpke's Palsies:

Features Erb's palsy Klumpke's Palsy
Causes

Undue separtion of head and shoulder. Upper plexus root involved. 

Eg.Shoulder dystocia at delivery, motor vehicle accidents

Hyperabduction of shoulder. Lower plexus root involved.

Eg. Difficult breech delivery, Holding on to something (e.g. a branch) during a fall, Cervical rib syndrome, Scalene syndrome
Nerves roots  C5 and C6 C8 and T1
Muscles involved

Deltoid, Supraspinatus - loss of abduction 

Infraspinatus - loss of lateral rotation 

Biceps brachii - loss of flexion and supination 

 All intrinsic muscles of the hand
Position of the upper limb/hand Policeman's tip/Waiter's tip/ Porter's tip position Claw hand
Sensory loss +/- Along the outer aspect of the arm Along the medial border of forearm and hand
ANS signs  Absent

Horner syndrome

questions.text: The device shown in the image is used as a primary feeding method during routine feeding in neonates with a gestational age of _______
questions.solution:
The given image shows paladai. It can be used as a primary feeding method during routine feeding in neonates born at gestational age 32-34 weeks.

Feeding of neonates depends on their gestational age as it depends on the level of maturity of the neonate.

Choice of initial feeding methods in low-birth-weight (LBW) infants

Gestational Age Feeding Skill Matured Method of Feeding
<28 weeks No proper sucking effort. No propulsive motility of the gut IV Fluids
28-32 weeks

Sucking bursts develop

No coordination between suck/swallow and breathing

 Oro-gastric/ Nasogastric tube feeding with occasional spoon/ paaladai feeding
32-34 weeks Slightly mature sucking pattern. Coordination between breathing and swallowing begins Feeding by spoon/paladai/cup
>34 weeks Mature sucking pattern. More coordination between breathing and swallowing Breastfeeding

questions.text: What is false about the condition, that is relieved by the technique shown in the picture?

choices.text: Presence of a frequent sighing during history taking

questions.solution:
The technique shown in the above image is of breathing in a bag technique. It relieves hypocapnia in hyperventilation syndrome.

Hyperventilation syndrome is a habit of hyperventilation due to stress or any emotional upheaval.

Symptoms occur due to hypocapnia due to carbon dioxide washout.

  • Fatigue, chest pain, dizziness, headache, palpitations, sweating.
  • If severe - carpopedal spasms, paraesthesias and loss of consciousness may occur.

Diagnosis:

  • Typical history of stress followed by symptoms. 
  • The patient frequently 'sighs' during the interview

Treatment: Breathing in a bag- The patient is told to breathe in and out of a bag, so that they rebreathe the expired air and thus increase the levels of arterial CO2. This quickly reverts the symptoms.

questions.text: The following catheter is used for?
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the Swan-ganz catheter used for pulmonary artery catheterization. It is also called the pulmonary artery catheter. The standard pulmonary artery catheter is 110 cm long with a 7.0 – 9.0 Fr circumference. 

Uses:

  • Measurement of pressures in right atrium, right ventricle and pulmonary artery
  • Indirect measurement of left atrial pressure through pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
  • Cardiac output
  • Oxygen saturation- pulmonary samples to rule out left-right shunt
  • Monitoring left ventricle filling pressure
  • Differentiate cardiogenic from non cardiogenic pulmonary edema

questions.text: Based on the given immunofluorescence image, identify the vesiculobullous disorder.
questions.solution:
This microscopic image of Direct immunofluorescence shows a characteristic “Fish-Net” appearance, seen in pemphigus Vulgaris due to IgG and C3 deposits in the epidermis.

Direct immunofluorescence uses anti IgG antibodies which detects the Anti-desmoglein IgG antibodies deposited on the Desmosomes which are present intercellularly.

Other patterns seen on Direct Immunofluorescens in Vesiculobullous disorders are:

Linear Pattern (shore line fluorescence pattern)

  • Due to linear IgG and C3 deposits along the DermoEpidermal Junctions (DEJ): Bullous Pemphigoid, Cicatricial Pemphigoid, Epidermolysis bullosa aquisita.
  • Due to linear deposits of IgA at DEJ: Linear IgA dermatosis

Linear deposits of immunoglobulin G and C3c along the basement membrane zone (shore line fluorescence pattern)

Dermatitis herpetiformis

Granular deposits of immunoglobulin A at the tips of the papillary dermis and along the basement membrane zone

questions.text: The Money bag heart is seen in:
questions.solution:
The Money bag heart is seen in pericardial effusion.

Plain PA chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette. There is effacement of the normal cardiac borders, development of a ‘flask’ or ‘water bottle’ cardiac configuration and bilateral hilar overlay which are features of pericardial effusion. It is also known as Money bag or leather bottle-shaped heart.

Investigation of choice: Echocardiography.

Signs on plain radiograph include:

  • Globular enlargement of the cardiac shadow giving a water bottle configuration.
  • Lateral CXR may show a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) separating a vertical lucent line directly behind the sternum (paracardial fat) anteriorly from a similar lucent vertical lucent line (epicardial fat) posteriorly; this is known as the Oreo cookie sign.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument?
questions.solution: The given instrument is a Unipolar Cautery.

questions.text: Which of the following investigation is shown in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
The contrast radiograph given above shows the stomach and the duodenum. This is a double contrast radiograph of barium meal.

Barium meal examines the lower half of esophagus, stomach, and entire duodenum.

Preparations and uses of barium sulfate as a contrast in GI imaging:

  • Barium swallow uses barium paste (for esothe phagus).
  • Barium meal- 95% BaSO4 (for stomach and duodenum).
  • Barium meal follow through - 50% BaSO4 (for small bowel).
  • Barium enema -25% BaSO4 (for large bowel).
  • For Single contrast films, barium alone is used. Double contrast films require air and barium which is better for small mucosal lesions.

The above radiograph shows a barium follow-through study. It is useful in visualising small bowel pathology.

Barium enema: contrast is administered through a rectal tube and series of radiographs are obtained. It still remains the investigation of choice to visualize fine mucosal detail and also a very good technique for demonstration of general colonic configuration and caliber. The above radiograph is double-contrast barium enema with normal large bowel structure.
